data.title: 8 Facts About Flannery OâConnor
data.meta_description: The writer, best known for her Southern gothic style, died at the age of 39 from lupus. Hereâs what you should know about her life.
data.text:
When it comes to violence, grotesque fiction, and a flair for irony, no Southern writer during the 20th century did it better than Flannery OâConnor. During her career, OâConnor published two novels and 32 short stories, many of which dealt with themes of religion and the Southern way of life, and she left behind numerous important works and helped change the perception of Southern literature.

OâConnor was an intensely shy and quirky author who decided to buy a peafowl family on a whim and wrote 600 letters to her mother as a young adult (sometimes about her love of mayonnaise)âand she also held many problematic views on race at the height of the Civil Rights movement. Ahead of the release of the biopic Wildcat, hereâs what you should know about Flannery OâConnor.

Flannery OâConnor originally wanted to be a professional cartoonist.

While Flannery OâConnor established herself as one of the most important authors of the 20th century, she originally set her sights on a career as an artist. She contributed witty cartoons to her high school and college publications, and according to Kelly Gerald, editor of Flannery OâConnor: The Cartoons, OâConnor saw art as a formative medium for storytelling. In an interview with Publisherâs Weekly, Gerald explained that, to OâConnor, âA story isnât about telling the reader something. A story is about showing. What the fiction writer had to learn, to be successful, was how to become a graphic artist.â

Gerald said that OâConnorâs love of drawing was eventually âabsorbedâ by her passion for writing, though later in life she would continue to paint.

She was intensely shy.

Paul Engle, director of the University of Iowaâs Writersâ Workshop in 1945, once recalled that OâConnor was so shy that he had to read her work out loud for her during workshops, and one classmate wrote that she never volunteered her insight during discussions. One fellow writer famously described her as âsome quiet, puritanical convent girl from the harsh provinces of Canada.â

OâConnor was racist.

When we dive into the personal lives of writers from the past, we run the risk of finding bigotry and ignorance, and itâs no different for OâConnor. The n-word was peppered throughout her letters with friends, and she scoffed at the idea of meeting James Baldwin in Georgia. In letters sent to playwright Maryat Lee in May 1964, OâConnor wrote âYou know, Iâm an integrationist on principle & a segregationist by taste anyway. I donât like negroes. They all give me a pain and the more of them I see the less and less I like them. Particularly the new kind.â She elaborated in another letter, âAbout the Negroes, the kind I donât like is the philosophizing prophesying pontificating kind, the James Baldwin kind. Very ignorant but never silent. Baldwin can tell us what it means to be a Negro in Harlem but he tries to tell us everything else too. ... My question is usually would this person be endurable if white. If Baldwin were white nobody would stand him a minute.â

She had a deep love of mayonnaise.

During OâConnorâs stay in Iowa City, she wrote to her mother every dayâand in a few of those letters, the subject at the top of her mind was a craving for mayonnaise, which was all but impossible to find near her school. According to the essay âA Good Mayonnaise is Hard to Findâ by David A. Davis in The Southern Quarterly [PDF], OâConnor âused mayonnaise as her universal condiment on both sweet and savory.â Eventually, she got her mother to send a jar of her fatty, yellow-white obsession to her dormâbut it wasnât the homemade version she had requested. Instead, her mother opted for a standard jar from the store.

OâConnor lived longer than her doctors predicted.

When she was diagnosed withsystemic lupus erythematosusâthe same disease that had taken her fatherâs life when she was a teenagerâin 1949, OâConnorâs doctors predicted that the then-25-year-old would only live five years. The symptoms, including chronic inflammation, forced her to move away from the friends she made in the Iowa workshop to return to her familyâs home in Georgia to live with her mother. Despite her declining health, OâConnor wasnât deterred from continuing her work, completing her two novels and 32 short stories while battling the disease. She lived another 14 years after her diagnosis, before passing away at age 39 on August 3, 1964.

She owned an assortment of birds.

At 5 years old, OâConnor had a pet chicken that she trained to walk backwards. The chicken gained so much local notoriety that it even became the subject of a PathÃ© newsreel that a young OâConnor appeared in. As an adult, OâConnor looked after geese, turkeys, mallard ducks, Japanese bantams, hens, and pheasants. And in the last years of her life, she developed a deep admiration for peacocks: One estimate says she owned more than 100 peacocks at Andalusia, the Georgia estate where she lived from 1951 until her death in 1964. She wrote two essays about the experience and even sent discarded feathers to close friends.

OâConnor penned more than 100 book reviews.

During her career, OâConnor was always the avid reader. Even as lupus took a toll on her health, she continued to write reviews for the Catholic diocesan newspapers, The Bulletin and The Southern Cross. The sharp reviews not only examined novels, but the works of popular theologists. David A. King contends she wrote for The Bulletin audience in particular to âdevelop not only their faith, but also their reason, their aesthetics, and their apologetics.â All of her reviews are collected in 1983's The Presence of Grace and Other Reviews, edited by Carter W. Martin.

Sheâs the subject of a new biopic directed by Ethan Hawke.

OâConner got the documentary treatment with 2019âs Flannery, and in 2024, sheâs getting a biopic: Wildcat, which follows OâConnor as she tries to get her novel published and weaves her stories throughout the narrative, hits theaters in May. The film was co-written and directed by Ethan Hawke and was the brainchild of his daughter Maya, who also stars.

Maya first read OâConnorâs work in 10th grade and even adapted a monologue from one of the authorâs works for her Juilliard audition. (She got in.) In an interview with Variety, the duo said they had discussions about whether they should make the movie, given OâConnorâs racist views. Ultimately, they decided that they were interested in making movies about people who, âin all of their faults ... are worth studying as a way of understanding the history of this country,â in Mayaâs words.
